title: How did WWII change machine gun tactics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Before World War II, machine guns were fundamentally regarded as specialized, heavier weapons. World War II’s biggest change to machine guns was an introduction to the LMG. Light Machine Guns generally had enough firepower to be used as mounted weapons where a larger weapon like a heavy machine gun or an auto cannon may not be viable, and yet were light enough to allow fully-automatic firepower on a squad-based level.  This was important, because Machine Guns, which are the only way to have sustained automatic fire and suppression, were no longer limited to vehicles and emplacements. Where necessary, a squad could easily separate the LMG into a few parts and carry it over long distances without using a vehicle. Parts for many LMGs were also relatively cheap to manufacture and easy to change in the field. The U.S. actually made use of a support weapon so light (20 lbs,) a single man could carry it.  The Browning Automatic Rifle, or BAR, which was a reasonable compromise between a rifle and a machine gun, was the U.S.’ choice of a suppression firearm that stayed beneath a weight class that would require it to be split into pieces, yet put out enough firepower to provide suppression. People got pretty creative about producing machine guns, and it quite literally changed the world. -Sam Images Used: MG42: http://www.deactivated-guns.co.uk/deactivated-guns/modern-deactivated-guns/deactivated-yugoslavian-mg42/m53-with-belt-and-rounds/prod_304.html?review=write Browning Automatic Rifle: http://www.historic-firearms.com/m1918a2-bar.html

The biggest change was the introduction of the general-purpose machine gun. During World War II most armed forces used medium machine guns which were designed to be fired from tripods and a separate magazine-fed light machine gun. The Germans had the idea of designing a belt-fed light machine gun  which could be used in both roles

WW2 did not fundamentally change the tactical use of Machine Guns, it continued the changes that had happened in the last 18 months of WW1 WW1 saw the introduction of the portable bipod MG like the Lewis, Chachat and MG08 which were used to provide mobile fire support intergral to infantry platoons (as opposed to the heavy tripod water cooled MGs like the Vickers ect The Interwar years saw the number of (what became called) LMG’s increasing from one per platoon to an everage of one per section The tactic these LMGs were used were virtually straight from the last years of WW1

The US Army certainly improved its tactics in countering enemy machine guns. At the company level they learned to use grenades and 60 millimeter mortars to take them out. At the battalion level they learned to use 81 mm mortars and artillery to take them out and tanks if they had them with their unit. When they had air support they could call in fighters or fighter-bombers to take them out as well.

An old question got renewed. Roman legions organized in three ranks, so that relief of exhausted troops became the standard. American Civil War battles had their monments where line troops ran out of ammo. On Guadalcanal, Bloody Ridge, John Basilone won the Congo.. in personally undertaking a MG resupply. (Vietnam as well different kinds of exhaustion showed.) The battlespace manager of today knows about ‘fire discipline’, resupply and unit rotation, at least in principle - demonstating those principles in practice would require an engaged “near-peer” adversary, which Heaven forfend. (mal’occhio)

In addition to other answers, machine guns in WW2 were much more mobile and were mounted on or in tanks, airplanes (fighters and bombers), jeeps, trucks, submarines and armored personnel carriers. They were more portable and were carried by most infantry units, in submachine gun form or as light machine guns firing belts of ammunition.
